data.title: RI is expected to get snow tomorrow. Here's how much, where parking bans are issued for
data.description:
The Providence Journal

RI is expected to get snow tomorrow. Here's how much, where parking bans are issued for

Katie Landeck, USA TODAY NETWORK - New England
February 5, 2025 at 8:58 AM·1 min read

It's time to start figuring out where to park your car ahead of the storm on Thursday as parking bans are being issued.

Tomorrow, Rhode Island is expected to get 2 to 3 inches of snow across most of the state, and between 1 to 2 inches along the coastline, according to the National Weather Service. A light glaze from ice is also possible.

A winter weather advisory has been issued for the state from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. The snow is expected to start mid-morning.

"Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes," the National Weather Service said.

Ahead of the storm, municipalities have started to issue parking bans. Here's where:

RI Parking Bans for Feb. 6

This list will be updates as more parking bans are announced.

  • Woonsocket: Parking ban in affect from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m.

  • North Kingstown: Parking ban in affect from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.

  • North Smithfield: Parking ban for Thursday morning.

  • Portsmouth: Parking ban from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.

More: Does your town have a parking ban? Here's where to leave your car during a snowstorm in RI

RI Snow forecast prediction map

Southern New England is expected to see between 1 and 4 inches of snow in the storm on Thursday.

Most of Rhode Island is expected to see 2 to 3 inches. Northern Massachusetts is expected to see the heavier snowfall.

This article originally appeared on The Providence Journal: RI Snow: See list of where parking bans have been issued for Thursday
data.summary: A winter weather advisory has been issued from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Thursday.
data.author: The Providence Journal

data.title: Popular Recalled Chocolate Brand Now Classified As 'Deadly'‚ÄîHere's What to Know
data.description:
Parade

Popular Recalled Chocolate Brand Now Classified As 'Deadly'‚ÄîHere's What to Know

Nathan Hutsenpiller
February 3, 2025 at 11:30 AM·2 min read

Last December, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) initiated a recall of a number of Cal Yee Farms‚Äô chocolate products, citing the potential for contamination with undeclared milk, soy, wheat, sesame, FD&C #6 and/or almonds. The FDA has since upgraded a select few of the affected products to the highest possible risk level: Class 1. Basically, those with dairy allergies might want to be extra careful with their chocolate consumption should they purchase their products from Cal Yee.

The FDA defines a Class 1 recall as ‚Äúa situation in which there is a reasonable probability that the use of or exposure to a violative product will cause serious adverse health consequences or death." The affected products that fall into this new classification include Cal Yee Farms dark chocolate almonds, dark chocolate apricots and dark chocolate walnuts; each of which have the potential of being contaminated with undeclared milk.

üòãüòã SIGN UP to get delicious recipes, handy kitchen hacks & more in our daily Pop Kitchen newsletter üç≥üçî

The initial December 2024 recall identified the affected chocolate products as being sold in Arizona, California, New Mexico, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia. These products were also sold online, however, so shoppers in other states are not entirely in the clear yet. Those who might have one of the listed products in question should check the labels immediately for the following information:

Recalled Cal Yee (or Cal Yee Farm branded) products were packaged in clear, plastic zippered pouches and came in 8-ounce, 1-pound, 2-pound and 5-pound sizes. Each product features a bright yellow label that identifies the product in front of the pouch, as well as a small white label containing a UPC code on the back of the pouch. All information, including UPC codes to look out for, can be found on the initial recall for your convenience.

Related: More Than 16,000 Pounds of This Pantry Staple Is Being Recalled Nationwide‚ÄîHere's What You Need to Know

As of the original publish date, no illnesses have been reported in relation to the unexpected contamination. Consumers with milk, soy, wheat, sesame, FD&C #6 and almond allergies or sensitivities that currently have the product in their possession should refrain from consuming altogether. Instead, please return the products for a full refund or dispose of them entirely. Consumers with further questions or concerns can reach out at (707) 425-5327 or mariatmail03@gmail.com) from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. PST, Monday through Friday.

Up Next:

Related: Target's Cutesy New Hello Kitty Valentine‚Äôs Day Mug Has Fans Clearing the Shelves Fast
data.summary: Check your stash as soon as you can.
data.author: Parade

data.title: Goodwill moving into old Ruby-Gordon space at Greece Ridge mall
data.description:
Democrat and Chronicle

Goodwill moving into old Ruby-Gordon space at Greece Ridge mall

Marcia Greenwood, Rochester Democrat and Chronicle
Updated February 5, 2025 at 9:58 AM·2 min read

Goodwill of the Finger Lakes is moving its store at 3654 Dewey Ave. in Greece into the former Ruby-Gordon space at the north entrance to The Mall at Greece Ridge, Goodwill announced Tuesday.

Doors will open at 9 a.m. on Friday, Feb. 28, following a ribbon-cutting ceremony, and Goodwill will give $10 gift cards to the first 100 shoppers.

The Greece Ridge location will start accepting donations between the hours of 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. from Wednesday, Feb. 5, until the Feb. 28 opening.

The Dewey Avenue store will close on Feb. 25.

Once the new location opens, store hours will be 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday through Saturday and 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday.

The mall store, which at 34,000 square feet is more than twice the size of the Dewey location, will have an exterior front entrance and one inside the mall next to the Monroe County Department of Motor Vehicles.

Like all Goodwill stores, it will sell apparel, household and seasonal merchandise and new items. But unlike at Dewey, the new location will be able to accept donations of larger items, including home furnishings, at a garage door in the back of the building.

In-store purchases will benefit Goodwill‚Äôs community-based services and programs, including Goodwill Vision Enterprises, 211/LIFE LINE & 988 and workforce development programs.

‚ÄúWe are excited to welcome Goodwill to The Mall at Greece Ridge in the coming weeks,‚Äù Greece Ridge general manager Jay Wilmot said in a statement. ‚ÄúGoodwill‚Äôs commitment to elevating individuals and strengthening the community aligns perfectly with our values at Greece Ridge. Their presence will not only enhance our retail mix but also provide greater value to both our shoppers and the local community we serve.‚Äù

Reporter Marcia Greenwood covers general assignments and has an interest in retail news. Send story tips to mgreenwo@rocheste.gannett.com. Follow her on X @MarciaGreenwood.

This article originally appeared on Rochester Democrat and Chronicle: Goodwill moving into old Ruby-Gordon space at Greece Ridge mall
data.summary: The new location is twice the size of the current one on Dewey Avenue.
data.author: Democrat and Chronicle

data.title: USPS accepting Chinese packages again: Alibaba, PDD, JD.com react
data.description:
Yahoo Finance Video

USPS accepting Chinese packages again: Alibaba, PDD, JD.com react

Yahoo Finance
February 5, 2025 at 10:10 AM

Chinese e-commerce platforms Pinduoduo (PDD), JD.com (JD), and Alibaba (BABA) are paring back stock losses, while remaining in the red, after the United States Postal Service (USPS) reversed its decision and will continue to accept inbound packages from China.

Yahoo Finance reporter Jordan Weissmann covers the latest developments.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here.

This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

data.title: Oklahoma State University President Kayse Shrum has resigned
data.description:
The Oklahoman

Oklahoma State University President Kayse Shrum has resigned

Cheyenne Derksen, The Oklahoman
February 5, 2025 at 8:34 AM·1 min read

Oklahoma State University President Kayse Shrum has resigned, the board of regents announced Wednesday.

The Oklahoma State University A&M Board of Regents accepted her resignation effective Feb. 3, according to a statement released by the board.

‚ÄúWe extend our deepest gratitude to Dr. Shrum for her dedicated leadership, unwavering commitment to students, and significant contributions to the OSU System," the statement reads.

Shrum, 52, guided Oklahoma State University in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic but also dealt with conference realignment and multiple public-relations headaches surrounding OSU‚Äôs high-profile football program.

She became the first woman to lead one of Oklahoma‚Äôs two research universities when OSU/A&M regents chose her to succeed Burns Hargis, effective July 1, 2021. Shrum, a doctor of osteopathic medicine, previously had been president of OSU‚Äôs Center for Health Sciences.

According to the statement, the board of regents will begin searching for the next OSU president and will ensure a "smooth transition" in the meantime.

‚ÄúWe thank Dr. Shrum for her service and wish her the very best in her future endeavors,‚Äù the statement read.

This article originally appeared on Oklahoman: Oklahoma State President Kayse Shrum resigns: What to know
data.summary: Oklahoma State University President Kayse Shrum has resigned after less than four years in office. The board has begun the search for her replacement.
data.author: The Oklahoman

data.title: Mass. bracing for potentially disruptive winter storm packing snow, ice. Here‚Äôs the latest timeline
data.description:
WFXT

Mass. bracing for potentially disruptive winter storm packing snow, ice. Here‚Äôs the latest timeline

Frank O'Laughlin
February 3, 2025 at 12:46 PM·1 min read

The Boston 25 Weather team is tracking a potentially disruptive winter storm that could bring snow, ice, and rain to Massachusetts later this week.

After a wintry system brought 1-3 inches of fresh snowfall to the Bay State late Sunday into early Monday, Meteorologist Shiri Spear issued a Weather Alert for Thursday due to an expected storm.

‚ÄúA wintry mix of snow and ice is currently expected to develop in the morning and continue through midday,‚Äù Spear wrote in her latest weather blog.

In her latest forecast, Spear said, ‚ÄúSnow and ice arrive at some point during the morning commute with a wintry mix and some slick travel through midday.‚Äù

The snow and ice will flip to rain during the afternoon, but the changeover might not happen everywhere, according to Spear.

‚ÄúIt only takes a coating of ice to really mess things up. As long as we get into that milder air, we‚Äôll be in good shape with showers in the afternoon. If this front is a little bit off and we never get that warm air moving into areas north and west of Boston, it could be slick there for travel all day.‚Äù

The Boston 25 Weather team has not yet issued a projected snow map for the storm.

There will also be a chance for a ‚Äúfast‚Äù weekend storm Saturday night into Sunday morning.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not thinking a lot of precipitation over the weekend, but we might need to add another weather alert,‚Äù Spear said.

To stay up to date with the latest forecast, visit the Boston 25 Weather page.

Download the FREE Boston 25 News app for breaking news alerts.

Follow Boston 25 News on Facebook and Twitter. | Watch Boston 25 News NOW
data.summary: The Boston 25 Weather team is tracking a potentially disruptive winter storm that could bring snow, ice, and rain to Massachusetts later this week.
data.author: WFXT

data.title: Colombia's president orders national oil company to cancel US venture over environmental concerns
data.description:
Associated Press

Colombia's president orders national oil company to cancel US venture over environmental concerns

MANUEL RUEDA
February 4, 2025 at 7:02 PM·2 min read

BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) ‚Äî Colombian President Gustavo Petro on Tuesday ordered the state-run oil company Ecopetrol to cancel a joint venture with a U.S.-owned company that was expected to produce around 90,000 barrels of oil per day, citing environmental concerns.

In a nationally televised speech, Petro said he opposed the recent extension of a deal between Ecopetrol and Occidental Petroleum, or Oxy, because it involved extracting oil through fracking, a controversial technique used to extract oil and gas from shale rock that has been criticized by environmental groups.

‚ÄúI want that operation to be sold, and for the money to be invested in clean energies,‚Äù Petro said in a meeting with his Cabinet that was livestreamed on social media. ‚ÄúWe are against fracking, because fracking is the death of nature, and the death of humanity.‚Äù

Ecopetrol had announced on Monday it would renew its operations with Oxy in the Permian basin, an oil producing region that spans Texas and New Mexico, to develop 91 oil wells, investing over $880 million.

Ecopetrol said its projects in the Permian basin produced an average of 95,200 barrels of oil per day in the first nine months of last year. Operations in the Permian basin made up around 12% of Ecopetol‚Äôs total production last year.

Ecopetrol, controlled by the Colombian government but also listed on the New York Stock Exchange, saw its shares rise 2% on Tuesday following the announcement of its deal with Occidental. However, they fell slightly after Petro called for the agreement's cancellation.

Colombia has refused to approve fracking projects on its territory, though it had not previously blocked Ecopetrol from taking part in fracking ventures overseas.

Environmentalists argue that fracking can pollute water sources and cause tremors.

____

Follow AP‚Äôs coverage of Latin America and the Caribbean at https://apnews.com/hub/latin-america
data.summary: Colombian President Gustavo Petro on Tuesday ordered the state-run oil company Ecopetrol to cancel a joint venture with a U.S.-owned company that was expected to produce around 90,000 barrels of oil per day, citing environmental concerns.  In a nationally televised speech, Petro said he opposed the recent extension of a deal between Ecopetrol and Occidental Petroleum, or Oxy, because it involved extracting oil through fracking, a controversial technique used to extract oil and gas from shale rock that has been criticized by environmental groups.
data.author: Associated Press

data.title: Dr. Kayse Shrum expected to resign as OSU President
data.description:
KFOR articles

Dr. Kayse Shrum expected to resign as OSU President

Tanner DeLeon/ KFOR
February 4, 2025 at 7:53 PM·2 min read

STILLWATER, Okla. (KFOR) ‚Äî News 4 has confirmed through two independent sources that Oklahoma State University President Dr. Kayse Shrum is expected to announce her resignation on Wednesday.

She has been on the job for less than four years.

During her tenure, Dr. Shrum led the way with the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and conference realignment, all while bringing new initiatives to the university: the Hamm Institute for American Energy, the Oklahoma Aerospace Institute for Research and Education, the Human Performance and Nutrition Research Institute, and the OSU Student Farm.

OSU has also set multiple enrollment records under Dr. Shrum, including the highest undergraduate enrollment, the largest first-time freshman class, and becoming the state’s largest university system.

The university also set records for non-residents, Honors College, Spears School of Business, Native American, first-generation, online, and new graduate students.

News 4 spoke with several OSU students on Tuesday who say they are in disbelief after hearing about the news.

“I hope it’s not true,” Jordan Mondaine, an OSU student said.

Students are trying to fathom the fact that Dr. Shrum is apparently stepping down.

“It feels a little, well, very kind of sad, to be honest,” said Nathan Wolmack, an OSU student. “It’s just like because she’s been here about as long as I have. I’ve been here as long as she has.”

Photo Gallery: Dr. Kayse Shrum begins her tenure as Oklahoma State University President

They say it feels like Dr. Shrum had just arrived yesterday, giving her speech about what she was going to do to improve the university.

“As a medical student at Oklahoma State University, I would have never imagined this day,” Dr. Shrum said when she was hired. “I’m so honored and humbled by this appointment. OSU has a special place in my heart and I’m thrilled at the opportunity to lead this vibrant university.”

Dr. Shrum became the 19th president of OSU in 2021 and is the first woman to lead the university.

“It was really cool to see her become the first woman president,” Wolmack said. “It was just like, it was nice. It’s like a big accomplishment for OSU as a whole.”

So far, no reason has been revealed as to why Dr. Shrum is resigning.

“She always showing support, seeing her always at the football games,” Mondaine said. “She’s great, being in touch with the student base and everything.”

Students that News 4 spoke with say they enjoyed their time at OSU while she was president.

“Just having her go would feel very strange because like all of a sudden, like, there might be some shakeups, something might change,” Wolmack said.

“I would hate to see her go,” Mondaine said. “I’d love to see her stay. And again, I understand things change, but again, we would love if you stayed out here, Dr. Shrum.”

News 4 will keep you informed when an official announcement is made.

Copyright 2025 Nexstar Media, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to KFOR.com Oklahoma City.
data.summary: News 4 has confirmed through two independent sources that Oklahoma State University President Dr. Kayse Shrum is expected to announce her resignation on Wednesday.
data.author: KFOR articles

data.title: US Postal Service flip-flops on Hong Kong-China packages, lifting a ban imposed a day earlier
data.description:
Associated Press

US Postal Service flip-flops on Hong Kong-China packages, lifting a ban imposed a day earlier

ZEN SOO
Updated February 5, 2025 at 8:25 AM·2 min read

HONG KONG (AP) ‚Äî The U.S. Postal Service is reversing course a day after placing a ban on all inbound mail and packages from China and Hong Kong.

The post office announced Tuesday that it would no longer accept parcels from the China and Hong Kong after the U.S. imposed an additional 10% tariff on Chinese goods and ended a customs exception that allowed small value parcels to enter the U.S. without paying tax.

The Postal Service gave no reason for the reversal, but said it would work with Customs and Border Protection to implement a collection process for the new China tariffs to avoid delivery disruptions.

The Postal Service did not immediately return a request for comment by the Requests for The Associated Press.

The ban had the potential to create massive disruptions for online shopping platforms like Shein and Temu, popular with younger shoppers in the U.S. for cheap clothing and other products, usually shipped directly from China.

Cheap, direct postal service helps these companies keep costs low, as did the ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù exemption that previously allowed shipments to go tax-free if their value is under $800.

The suspension by USPS would have likely have created delays in shipments and potentially higher prices for the companies that rely on rock-bottom pricing for huge sales.

What exactly did the USPS announce?

One day after the U.S. Postal Service said in a notice that it would stop accepting inbound parcels from the China and Hong Kong Posts until further notice, it said Wednesday that would ‚Äúcontinue accepting all international inbound mail and packages from China and Hong Kong.‚Äù

Letters and flats ‚Äî mail that measures up to 15 inches (38 centimeters) long or 3/4 inches (1.9 centimeters) thick ‚Äî were not included in the brief ban.

Why did it happen?

The USPS did not give a reason for the ban Tuesday, but the suspension came after Trump closed the ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù customs exemption this week that allowed shoppers and importers to avoid duties on packages worth below $800.

The exemption was removed as part of an executive order to levy a 10% tariff on Chinese goods.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection previously stated that it processes an average of over four million ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù imports each week.

It also gave no reason for its decision on Wednesday and did not immediately respond to requests from The Associated Press for comment.
data.summary: The U.S. Postal Service is reversing course a day after placing a ban on all inbound mail and packages from China and Hong Kong.  The post office announced Tuesday that it would no longer accept parcels from the China and Hong Kong after the U.S. imposed an additional 10% tariff on Chinese goods and ended a customs exception that allowed small value parcels to enter the U.S. without paying tax.  The Postal Service gave no reason for the reversal, but said it would work with Customs and Border Protection to implement a collection process for the new China tariffs to avoid delivery disruptions.
data.author: Associated Press

data.title: ‚ÄòPossible sinkhole‚Äô closes part of Highway 1 as atmospheric river storm hits Central Coast
data.description:
San Luis Obispo Tribune

‚ÄòPossible sinkhole‚Äô closes part of Highway 1 as atmospheric river storm hits Central Coast

Kaytlyn Leslie
February 4, 2025 at 10:22 PM·1 min read

Update, 9:40 p.m.:

Highway 1 has reopened in both directions after briefly closing due to a possible sinkhole Tuesday night, Caltrans said.

The agency said it will ‚Äúcontinue to monitor conditions on the roadway with repairs to be scheduled.‚Äù

Original story:

A ‚Äúpossible sinkhole‚Äù closed part of Highway 1 in Santa Barbara County as an atmospheric river storm hit the Central Coast on Tuesday evening.

According to a Caltrans post on X, the highway was closed from Highway 101 north of Gaviota to Highway 246 near Lompoc.

The incident began around 4:40 p.m. with a report that the bridge on Highway 1 just south of Jalama Road was ‚Äúgiving way‚Äù on the southbound side, according to the California Highway Patrol‚Äôs traffic incident report page.

Soon after, first responding agencies began the process of closing the road.

As of 8 p.m., Caltrans was inspecting the roadway to assess the damage.

There was no estimated time for re-opening.

The closure comes as an atmospheric river storm dropped heavy rain across much of the Central Coast on Tuesday evening.

Some parts of Santa Barbara County were expected to get as much as 3 inches of rain during the storm, though most of the area would see between 0.75 and 1.5 inches, according to the National Weather Service.

San Luis Obispo County, meanwhile, was under a flood advisory due to heavy rainfall.

Highway 1 is closed from #US101 north of Gaviota to the Junction with State Route 246 near Lompoc in Santa Barbara County due to a possible sink hole. Caltrans is inspecting the roadway to assess damage. There is no estimated time for re-opening.@CaltransHQ pic.twitter.com/oB6YHwEY19

‚Äî Caltrans District 5 (@CaltransD5) February 5, 2025
data.summary: A report came in late Tuesday afternoon that a bridge along the roadway was ‚Äúgiving way‚Äù
data.author: San Luis Obispo Tribune
